Maybe it's too many recent films, but wouldn't he have gotten suspicious pretty quick?  It really doesn't ruin the movie because you could come up with plenty of reasons.  Tailing the kidnapper leads the police through the poorer region of the same city that Gondo lives.  The club where he gets the drugs is crowded and hot.  Then there is a specific place that holds all the junkies.  In here we see a woman who is having withdrawals, and the kidnapper takes her to test the heroin to make sure it is pure enough to kill her.  I think the sickest part of this is seeing the police talk to each other like they know they are heading towards junkie central and they know they are about to head to a whore house.  They're poor, who cares?  The capture of the kidnapper is a little underwhelming, but that's because Kurosawa is saving the best punch for last.  Gondo is told the next day that the police retrieved the money except for 20,000 which was spent on the heroin, and while they are telling him the good news Gondo is getting all of his things repossessed.  He is embarrassed, but his family will make it.  The kidnapper requests to see Gondo and he agrees, and basically we discover that he did it simply because he was tired of looking at his nice house on the hill while everyone suffered.  During this scene there is a reflection on the mirror, pretty much showing that they are both feeling some of the same things; they are man, they are similar.  The kidnapper says the poor like to see the rich go through pain too.  I expected the kidnapper to be tied in with the men at the company who wanted Gondo out, so it was surprising to hear the connection wasn't there.  I think that's the strongest punch of them all.  Kurosawa leaves his audience thinking about sociological differences while entertaining them to no ends with a brilliantly crafted crime story.
finally, something a little more relatable in the kurosawa anthology. that said, still about average. also, still too long (kurosawa's trademark)
two great separate films in one, one of the best crime drama movies i've seen

As is true in society, this movie demonstrates that the womenâs shoe industry is a dangerous place.  Our hero, who is planning on taking control over the shoe company he works for through some pretty slick negotiations, must put that plan on hold when his son is kidnapped for 30 million yen.  Then the plan is back on when he realizes the kidnapper made off with his chaufferâs kid, not his own.  False alarm, guys.  Except here comes the morality bit (and the filmâs strongest third) in that we have to ask how valuable the life of a human is.  Ten minutes ago, Mifune was ready to pay the ransom despite the fact it would bankrupt him.  But when the victim isnât his own flesh and blood, he starts to ease up.  Dramatics and interesting staging make the apartment where the entire first 42 minutes take place the best part, with Mifune being Mifune (but wearing a shirt this time) and the police assigned to the job trying to track the kidnapper via phone conversations.  The wheels start to come off when we shift to Mifune paying the ransom in a very clever train sequence.  After that, our focus is with the police trying to figure out who did this (we find out pretty quickly) and why (thatâs a bit tougher).  Youâll be forgiven for thinking youâve wandered into a second movie on your DVD by mistake.  But then the last third starts and we follow the kidnapper through the drug-infested lower depths of Japanese culture in the 1960s (read: drugs, dancing and making drug deals while dancing).  What should be exciting and engaging is dull, repetitive and downright heavy handed on a symbolic level.  Kurosawaâs better than this, sure, but when weâre constantly reminded of the âhighâ and âlowâ of the title (Mifune lives atop a hill, high above the poor citizens, the street-level drug-laced culture is a living hell, etc.), itâs not exactly thought provoking anymore.  Then again, this was adapted from a book I havenât read, so maybe itâs even worse in the book and Kurosawa smoothed out the blatant symbolism.  No idea.  But if youâre out to tear through all the Kurosawa-Mifune collaborations, this is one that can wait.

An excellent thriller if not a little long but still works. Especially the first half...where the main character is faced with an overwhelming moral dilemma - to resue another's child or to save himself from financial ruin. The second half-is more of a police procedural but very detailed and the plot twists keep things interesting.

Akira Kurosawa can do no wrong when it comes to making films. That especially goes for this modern neo noir thriller starring Toshiro Mifune as  high ranking shoe executive, Kingo Gondo who makes a play for controlling shares of the company because he shares the founder's vision of quality over quantity. His rivals want to make higher quantities of shoddy made shoes. While this struggle is taking place a man kidnaps the son of Gondo's chauffeur who the kidnapper mistakes for Gondo's son. Upon learning the mistake he made the kidnapper still demands the same ransom for his chauffeur's son knowing Gondo won't let the child die. The first half of the film deals with Gondo's moral dilemma and the second half deals with the dragnet put up by Inspector Tokura(Nakadai) and his police squad to bring the kidnapper to justice.

Kurosawa sizes up class difference, judgment, morality, and relativity among a host of philosophical topics in his modern High and Low.  As with his earlier modern day business tale, Ikiru, High and Low is split into two parts.  The first, dedicated to Mifune's stern self made business man split between the decision to spend his fortune saving his chauffer's son.  The second part is dedicated to the police search.  Although Kurosawa meant a nod towards film noir, the movie sides less with solo-detective banter and investigation and instead sprawls a careful and concise city wide investigation.  The detail unravels slowly, and the suspense keeps us hanging, but underneath it all is the consistently present question of who we should be rooting for, and what bigger issues are at play behind the crime.  A perfect blend of subtle social examination and genre typical excitement.

While my knowledge of the Japanese language is almost non-existent, I do know that the word "jigoku" means "hell," so "Heaven and Hell" is probably the more literal translation. Heaven and Hell also fits with the speech at the film's end, but High and Low also works well as a title to this film. For starters, High and Low functions as a film noir type title that refers to the the police searching "high and low" for the kidnapper in the film. But, even more importantly, High and Low refers to the social classes at odds with one another throughout the film.

Whatever title you give it in English, Kurosawa's kidnapping thriller is a taunt potboiler of a police drama as well as a philosophical parable. For the entire first hour of the film, Kurosawa keeps the film in the same room as the kidnapping is revealed and the father speaks on the phone with the kidnapper. In this lengthy opening sequence (and throughout the film), Kurosawa proves himself to be a master of blocking and triangulation as characters' positions to one another becomes a crucial visual embodiment of the underlying tensions and themes of the films.

After leaving the apartment of the opening hour, High and Lows features a breathtaking variety of locations, characters, and situations: a money exchange on a moving train, double homicides, junkies, dance clubs, the 1960s Japanese equivalent of crack houses, etc.

Aside from being a thoroughly engaging thriller, High and Low is also an excoriating look at the nature of class hierarchy and capitalist business practices. Indeed, if there is a true villain in the film, it is the rapacious greed that underlies big business and causes it to act without any regard to ethics, duty, friendship, family, or emotion. High and Low portrays the cold, dead, mathematical heart that drives the heartless body of such businesses. Like all great Kurosawa films, High and Low functions as a piece of pure entertainment while also harboring a deep and complex series of themes and social critiques underneath.

Dilemma.Sacrifice.Envy.Greed.The whole distinction of the needy and the greedy, the upper crest of the society and the bottom dwellers are the epitome of all elements in this noir crime epic of Kurosawa.Again its a masterpiece.

High and Low deals with Kurosawa's familiar themes: Justice, evil, good, glory, humanity and morality. It is a moral study, but it also shows the themes of good and evil on different layers, in the business interests as it does in the slum. There truly are Heavens and Hells in our world. In the beginning Kurosawa challenges us to think what is the right thing for Gondo to do, Mr. Gondo gets the sympathy of the media and the sympathy of the audience. But eventually we start to think who actually are the real victims. The way how Akira Kurosawa deals with humanity in this is perfect. He achieves to create new humane experiences for us. I think no one has made as many masterpieces as he has. High and Low challenges us to observe and think. To look at our own morality. Can the world where some people live in heaven and some in hell be even close to justice? Would the police have helped Gondo as much if he was a middle-class worker?It studies the true nature of justice while showing the good and evil in our world. It is a philosophical moral thrill ride that only Akira Kurosawa could take us on

Terrific kidnap & ransom crime thriller directed by Akira Kurosawa. I got to see this at a film festival and it kept me on the edge of my seat in black and white with no special effects and only two actors I knew by name.

Kurosawa was a crafty director, Coherent in everything. Almost 99% the 1st hour were shot in a single room, which made the storyboard alongside with the editing extremely remarkable, no matter how classical they were.
It's not one of Kurosawa's masterpieces, but 'High and Low' fully illustrates why Kurosawa is regarded as Japan's foremost director.

This film can be split into two parts: the first is an examination of a moral dilemma, the second is a police procedural with a liberal lathering of film noir styling. For once it was nice to see Toshiro Mifune not play a samurai. Instead, he plays a millionaire businessman who has to pay the ransom for his chauffeur's son. Some beautiful, crafted images in the second half will particularly delight aficionados of B&W lighting and shot framing. The ending is perfect as a film noir plot would have required, even if most of this film was not made with that aesthetic. One of the best Kurosawas. Wish he had made more plots set in the cities and rooted in modernity.

possibly Kurosawa's most suspenseful movie. if i could best compare this to anything, it would be Fritz Lang's "M" merely because of how the crime situation is handled, except this is actually taken into the law's hands and it is much more complex than "M". like all Kurosawa films, the acting is superb and the cinematography is to perfection - its basically the ideal Kurosawa film, a type of film which is, and always will be, at the top of the 'film pyramid' (if you will).
This is a gripping thriller with a mixture of social commentary. It's a terrific film and a pleasant departure from Kurosawa's typical samurai fare.
Another Kurosawa crime classic with a ransom story first half and a detective story second half.  The acting and story are quite good, as is Kurosawa's masterful direction.  An all around great film.
my favorite film from the legendary Akira Kurosawa!

El maestro Akira Kurosawa se sale de sus tradicionales cintas historicas para adaptar la novela policiaca de Ed McBain "King Ransom's" y crear asi un clasico del Film Noir.  Toshiro Mifune interpreta a un industrial del calzado que es presionado por unos codiciosos ejecutivos y a la vez debe decidir que hacer ante el secuestro del hijo de su chofer, a quien confunden con su propio hijo.  "High And Low" es una cinta de suspenso que a la vez sirve como comentario social y ejercicio etico.

El maestro Akira Kurosawa se sale de sus tradicionales cintas historicas para adaptar la novela policiaca de Ed McBain "King Ransom's" y crear asi un clasico del Film Noir.  Toshiro Mifune interpreta a un industrial del calzado que es presionado por unos codiciosos ejecutivos y a la vez debe decidir que hacer ante el secuestro del hijo de su chofer, a quien confunden con su propio hijo. Proof that Kurasawa and Mifune could do more more than samurai  films, and that they can do them well.  I  look foward to watching more of his other modern day films-Stray Dog, Drunken Angel and Ikiru. (Well modern compared to his period pieces)

Kurosawa makes this film so much more than its fairly straightforward kidnapping plot suggests: the carefully framed scenes in Gondo's house contrasting with the more frenetic and close-up scenes in the kidnapper's apartment; the wonderful build of suspense in the film's first half; and the use of reflections in the stunning and unexpected conversation that abruptly concludes the film. The film reminds us not to forget our common humanity, even as certain actions separate one from another.

One of Kurosawa's least talked about films but definitely one of the greatest. But then again, did Kurosawa ever make a bad film. the whole movie is astonishing. The first hour alone takes place entirely in one room, but don't be fooled. This one grabs you and doesn't let go until it's over.

I liked this film a lot, it was something different from Kurosawa, because all the films I saw so far were like period films. It was interesting to see him direct a crime drama. It's very well made. Mifune was my favorite, Nakadai, Kagawa, Yamazaki, and the rest of the cast acted well too. I would rate it 3.5/5, watch it!

A nice and tight, and unexpectedly realistic, Kurosawa movie. It starts out as almost a chamber play with all the tension mounting in one room with painful but interesting existential questions, then completely switches to a nailbiting crime mystery. Top notch all around.

Incredibly engrossing, impeccably acted and beautifully shot, "High and Low" is a taut, suspenseful gem.  The mise en scene is extraordinary; it seems as though each shot could be a painting.  The only reason I held back from giving it the full five stars is that the resolution left me mildly dissatisfied.  Just a minor quibble against a film that is in all other respects Kurosawa's best, at least in my mind.
One of the best Kurosawa movies i've seen yet. Definitely shows Toshiro Mifune's range as an actor, how he can do a role like this and Yojimbo AND Rashomon, I definitely see why he's the greatest!

Wednesday March 24, 2010

(1962) High and Low
(In Japanese with English subtitles)

THRILLER/ DRAMA
  
  Like "Ransom" where the father's son gets kidnapped, this adds a whole new spin to that kind of genre where it's not the father's son that gets captured but the chauffers son. And there's a little cat and mouse where it's always fascinating how the police work together to capture this perpetrator.  The only problem with the overall film is that the film feels a little out dated but does an extremely good job about debating it's complicated situations regarding the ransom.


3 out of 4
The best of the  Mifune-Kurosawa magic along with "Yojimbo".

So much more than the sum of its parts: at first a chamber play, then a thriller, then a procedural, and finally, a chilling dramatic portrait of inner-city mid-century Japan, boosted by cleverly framed b&w cinematography.
"I see why people hate that house...it feels like it's looking down on us"

Another master piece by Akira Kurosawa, am beginning to become fan of his, his direction, editing and photography make current cinematographers look pale.

This  is a gripping tale of intelligent kidnapping and equally intelligent police work. Story  telling is superb, very logical - no cliches whatsoever.

Akira Kurosawa handles camera angles very well. The way scenes are composed, way characters move into scene and panning of camera make his movies stand out.

Watch this movie if you love suspense with substance.
Master piece. Interesting to compare with movie I watched last week, "Sinayakana Kedamono"

"High and Low" is an example of the Kurosawa and Mifune work at its best and demonstrates their capable teamwork removing the shackles of chanbara/ jidaigeki (samurai sword films/ period epic films) approaching a ransom tension story (from then) a modern day 1960's Japan point of view. (It is loosely based on a book called "King's Ransom," and "High and Low" later helped 'inspire' the Mel Gibson film "Ransom.") The basic premise is about Toshiro Mifune who plays an executive that has to choose between the ownership of his company or the life of his son. In between Kurosawa emphasizes some of his common film issues such as the divide between rich and poor with the juxtaposition of beautiful houses overlooking the slums, and in this case it works into the plot. With "High and Low" director Kurosawa puts together a well thought out production with the highlight being the direction in a smart and taught train ransom scene worth seeing. 4 stars.

Very compelling crime drama with fine acting split in two parts--tjhe actual kidnapping and recovery of the child, and the police investigation that entails.  Both parts hold your interest  and the final scene is haunting.  See it.

Another Kurosawa classic, resorting to nothing but good storytelling, this is a masterfully produced and directed crime / thriller. The tension and progress is well crafted and incredibly interesting (the Police's highly methodical investiation is gripping stuff). 'High and Low' is a damn good film.

Kurosawa's moral lesson/crime drama. The moral lesson starts out the film by way of a kidnapping. A shoe factory exec has a kid stolen. While it's his own kid that is the intended target, the napped one ends up being the son of his driver. The kidnapper realizes this, but poses the same ransom regardless. Now the shoe exec has to decide to break his family or let the boy die. This hour is where I degraded my rating a bit. The dilemma is hardly an even trade and it seems false to build a dialogue around it, where all the exec's underlings can placate his wavering integrity.

Regardless of his deceision, the police still get to spend the rest of the movie hunting for the kidnapper/maybe-child killer. This is where Kurosawa really excels. Remember, this is 1963 Japanese standards, so it's actually quite amazing to see actual footwork and logic carry the story out instead of the usual computer-simulation recreation of events. It doesn't delve into the family issues of the lead investigator; it doesn't feign some secret conspiracy sub-plot- it just goes by the numbers for a large group of men doing a job to piece clues together to single out a individual(s).

The direction and acting are very purposeful and exacting without getting over-flashy or stylinsh, for the most part. The exception to this comes when we follow a suspect through the drug dins of Japan to see how a rock and roll dance becomes a very romantic heroin purchase. This is followed by an almost Salvadore Dali-surrealist walk through an addict maze. It's very dark and disturbing and points to the ugliness of our kidnapper in a way that we hadn't seen otherwise.

To that end, we get very little of the perpetrator(s) of the crime. The motive, the demeamor, for example. This comes through in the ending with great results. The direction in these scenes is such that we see victims and victimisors reflected within each other. A great ending for a great ride.

One of my favorite movies!
I think this is the greatest movie which theme is kidnapping.
The tempo of this movie makes me glued to the screen.
My favorite Kurosawa film, perfect for an Indonesian remake.

Based on King's Ransom, a crime novel by Ed McBain, High and Low (Tengoku to Jigoku) stars Toshiro Mifune as Kingo Gondo, a wealthy, hardworking businessman who owns a certain percentage of a shoe company that has seen better days. As Gondo plans a move that will secure his position as the head of his company, he is contacted by a mysterious man who informs him that he has kidnapped his son. The crook demands a high ransom - one that is so huge it will bankrupt him. As Gondo is prepared to pay the ransom, he discovers that his son is actually safe at home and the kidnappers have mistakenly kidnapped the chauffeur's son. As quick as he was to pay off the man for his son, he is reluctant to pay him off for the son of the chauffeur and the question quickly becomes: does Gondo abandon his plans to pay off the man or does he do the honorable thing and help save his driver's son? This moral dilemma is what drives the first half of Akira Kurosawa's thriller which mainly takes place in the spacious living room inside of the Gondo residence full of long takes and a tour de force of acting and directing. The second half however is mainly set in the cramped confines of the city where the kidnapper hides from the police investigation led by the Inspector Tokura, played by Tatsuya Nakadai. The investigation scenes are done with great attention to detail and for the most part are very fast paced, compared to the long takes of the first half. Scenes that come to mind are when the kidnapper is being followed through out the city into a club where there is a crowd of people dancing around and where an exchange of money and drugs is thought to happen. The police, in disguises, follow the kidnapper into a place where many drug addicts are located waiting for a chance to score and soon after finding a dead woman overdosed off of pure heroin the men go back into the streets where the kidnapper is seen by Inspector Tokura and his men in the car speaking with Gondo although Gondo has absolutely no idea that this is the man they are looking for. This scene is one of the scenes where it shows just how much of a fan Kurosawa must have been of film noir. The film ends with the kidnapper confronting with Gondo while being locked up.

While it may or may not be one of his true master works it is a fine example of Japanese film noir. It is helped by a fantastic cast that includes Kurosawa regulars Toshiro Mifune, Tatsuya Nakadai, Takashi Shimura and Susumu Fujita. It has great camera work and while the first act is done mostly with long takes, the second and third acts have fabulous editing that give the film suspense and energy. The acting during the scenes in the Gondo residence, along with the police procedurals of the second act and the conclusion of the kidnapper confronting Gondo all adds up to one of the best detective films ever made. Not many Hollywood movies in the genre can compare to it. Just a great film to watch and a must see for fans of film noir and of course the usual Kurosawa fans. 10/10

Another Kurosawa film I never really learned how to appreciate. As often with his films, I felt here as well that nothing was exactly wrong, the movie had a solid subject and some very good scenes, but the whole of it just left me unimpressed. I guess I lack the sensitivity for nuance that appreciating this story requires.
Damn near perfect rendering of a modern crime story. Mifune shines as a stubborn industrialist whose world is turned inside out. Great photography of 60s Tokyo.
This has to be the MOTHER of all ransom movies. simply outstanding, unbelievable film making and ridiculously gripping!
Kurosawa's use of composition within the wide screen frame is awe-inspiring. High and Low works both as a suspenseful crime drama, and a commentary on classes in society.

A very slow build in the first half of the movie turns into an interesting crime drama in the second half. I loved the soundtrack. It was sparse and helped intensify the atmosphere and gravity of any given situation in the film. Mifune played yet another character-type in this film since his character is very firm, but mostly reactive to other people's decisions. He's very stoic in most of the film, which is unusual to see from him. Tatsuya Nakadai also played a very different character than I'm used to seeing from him, along the same lines as Mifune's. I love the way the detectives work in this film. It's a really terrific mystery that unravels bit by bit and makes it seem like you're there with them; you're hoping to find the culprit just as they are. Great stuff again from Kurosawa.

A police procedural from Kurosawa. Not my favorite from the master, but worth a look. 
Strong performances and an engaging story - a bit on the talky side.
Better than Hitchcock.

ENTRE LE CIEL ET L'ENFER est le titre franÃ§ais de ce film policier genial.
Toshiro Mifune y joue un Self made man de l'industrie de la chaussure qui a reussi brillamment puisqu'il s'apprete a racheter l'entreprise dans laquelle il a debute.
Un homme au sommet donc, mais pour peu de temps... Le film commence par un huis-clos de 50 minutes terribles, ou l'industriel va apprendre que son fils vient d'etre enleve. On lui reclame une somme exorbitante... Il risque de tout perdre. Mais aussitot ce drame noue, on apprend que le ravisseur s'est trompe et a enleve le fils du chauffeur. Dilemne: sauver ce fils qui n'est pas le sien ou sa fortune ? L'enquete de Police passionnante qui se deroule alors n'auras au fond qu'un seul but: demontrer que depuis ces hommes des bas-fonds, des petites gens, des junkies, des modestes aux plus hauts sommets de l'echelle sociale, a ces riches parvenus ou issus de l'aristocratie, nous nous ressemblons tous au point de nous confondre. Le face a face final entre le riche industriel et le ravisseur acheve de nous convaincre... la seule chose qui separe les deux hommes, au fond, n'est que la pure injustice de l'existence... Qui a fait de nous ce que nous sommes ?

A exemplary piece of editing, a social commentary on the upcoming doom of sub-prime mortgages (and the dreaded guilt that followed), a personal study of how much man is willing to sacrifice, and an intense crime investigation drama...all rolled into one. "High and Low" is one of those rare films that come along and set the bar for every film following. There's no faulty note. In the era of "CSI", this may seem old. But Kurosawa completed this film in 1963! There are no words for how far ahead Kurosawa was - technically, narratively, and emotionally. This film is provocative, engaging and brilliantly crafted. You feel trapped, torn, and bewildered - but always safe because your in the hands of a genius like Kurosawa.
Holy crap this was excellent.  Riveting stuff.
This and Ikiru are the best non-samurai Kurosawa films.  Everything about this movie is enthralling.

The title of Akira Kurosawa's 1963 noir thriller "High and Low" is both a reflection of the setting in which much of the action takes place in, as well as a portrait of the class boundaries separating the industrial slums from the mansion that rests atop a hill. The film stars the longtime Kurosawa mainstay Toshiro Mifune (Takashi Shimura turns up as well, but in a much smaller roll), and it is arguably Kurosawa's best non-period piece.

Kingo Gondo (Toshiro Mifune) is a top level executive at the National Shoe Company, which is in the process of a huge reform to maximize profitability. Although his associates are fine with producing less-than-stellar products, Gondo takes a great pride in his shoes and angrily rejects. Fearing the future of the company in their hands, he plans to become the majority shareholder and keep the NSC from producing poor footwear.

After mortgaging everything and arranging a big business deal, Gondo gets a call at home saying that his son, Jun (Toshio Egi), was kidnapped. In actuality, Jun was mistaken for Shinichi (Masahiko Shimazu), the son of Aoki (Yutaka Sada), Gondo's chauffeur. Although Gondo was willing to give up his money to protect the life of his own son, he recklessly calls the police (despite the kidnappers saying police involvement will lead to the death of the boy) and refuses to pay for Shinichi's life. 

The police and Gondo eventually set up a foolproof method of catching the criminals while delivering the ransom money, but they are fooled. Shinichi is back in the hands of his father, but the rest of the film follows the police's pursuit of the kidnapper and Gondo's fortune.

The first half of the film, dealing with Gondo and the kidnappers, is simply brilliant. Gondo's apartment is filled with a number of people, and each actor plays their roles wonderfully. Gondo's wife chastises Gondo for not saving Shinichi, and Aoki lingers in the backdrop as a nervous and pathetic wreck. When the story shifts to the slums and the cat-and-mouse chase between the cops and the kidnapper, it becomes more of a standard police procedural - however the perfectly realized drug and prostitution culture make it never less than fascinating to look at.

Although the second half of "High and Low" doesn't reach the brilliance of the first, it's nevertheless a wonderful thriller that criticizes the cruelty of capitalism in a creative and new fashion.

Finally a Kurosawa film that I love. The guy's ridiculously overrated but High and Low strikes well with me because the minimal suspense sticks with you throughout the investigation. There's flawed directing choices (Over acting lead actors, moments aware of a filming camera) but at least it's not another samurai film.
Brilliant crime drama!!
Being a westerner I found this movie a little hard to follow. I don't know why I just couldn't get that into it.
Fantastic. Seriously, it's worth watching.
Very dark Noir, also an interesting character study and social commentary.

Kurosawa's epic thriller; like most of his best movies this is about as good and as interesting as narrative film gets. Tightly pieced together and perfectly paced; with interesting social commentary. Last scene is worth the whole movie; unusually dark for Kurosawa.

Easily my favourite Akira Kurosawa film so far. A film of two halves, the first half taking place in a house at the 'high' top of a hill, and the second half exploring the 'low' underbelly of Japan.

The movie begins with the main character's power struggle for the company he works for. He is trying to stop his shareholder colleagues from making shoddy shoes. Then his son is kidnapped, and after some unfolding events it turns into a fascinating morality tale.

After the tense build up of the ransom and drop, the investigation continues as the police use every method possible to catch the kidnapper. The movie has a slow pace, but an incredible absorbing feel to it. Its almost as if you're in the room with them as they utilize clues and testimonies.

The movie ends with a final confrontation full of tension. The kidnapper's mirrored sunglasses are used to full effect, and its filmmaking at its absolute finest. Akira Kurosawa makes a tense and methodical crime thriller that explores the depravity, morality, and integrity of human nature.

Un chef d'oeuvre de film policier, magnifiquement orchestre par Akira Kurosawa. Le scenario d'"Entre le Ciel et l'Enfer", inspire d'un roman americain ("Rancon sur un theme mineur" d'Ed McBain), est demoniaque : Gondo (Toshiro Mifune), un businessman japonais parti de rien, qui a gravi bareau par bareau l'echelle sociale, est en passe de realiser l'affaire de sa vie, en hypothequant ses biens pour racheter la fabrique de chaussures qui l'emploie, quand un homme lui annonce par telephone qu'il a kidnappe son fils... mais il y a eu meprise : l'enfant capture est en fait le fils de son chauffeur. Une rancon est exigee et Gondo devra choisir entre la vie du garcon et sa propre ruine... la premiere heure du film peut derouter car Kurosawa fait le choix radical du huis-clos et de l'unite de lieu. Tout se deroule dans la maison de Gondo, facon "theatre filme" (les rideaux sur la grande baie vitree sont fermes, puis ouverts, comme sur une scene). Le realisateur joue sur le hors-champ et le positionnement des personnages qui apparaissent puis disparaissent du cadre. Ils se croisent, echangent leurs places, dans une etrange choregraphie, ronges par le stress, guettant avec anxiete chaque nouveau coup de fil du kidnappeur. Ce huis-clos etouffant nous fait violemment ressentir le dilemme vecu par Gondo, les sentiments contradictoires qui l'animent... Toshiro Mifune livre d'ailleurs dans cette premiere partie du film un numero d'acteur epatant. Puis Kurosawa opere une rupture nette, avec une superbe sequence de remise de rancon dans un train filant a toute allure, camera subjective a l'epaule, montage cisele. Les silhouettes furtives des kidnappeurs postes au bord de la voie ferree, apercus derriere les vitres des wagons, accentue l'angoisse, le sentiment d'impuissance.... c'est le climax du film. Puis la police entre en jeu. Kurosawa restitue son enquete de facon tres posee, en rassemblant avec application chaque piece du puzzle, jusqu'au denouement final. Paradoxalement, plus les flics progressent, plus la lumiere faiblit. L'obscurite finit par s'imposer dans la poursuite finale dans les bas-fonds de Yokohama ou l'on croise les silhouettes fantomatiques des toxicomanes, des prostituees... les laisses pour compte de l'essor economique japonais. A travers ce film, Kurosawa nous questionne effectivement sur le sens de la reussite economique, individuelle et collective, sans jamais se poser en moralisateur car il se garde bien d'apporter une reponse toute faite... il nous laisse reflechir, seuls, comme Gondo a la fin du film, dans un dernier plan sublime. Mike Nichols, le realisateur du "Laureat",  preparerait un remake hollywoodien d'"Entre le Ciel et l'Enfer" pour le compte de Miramax, reprenant un projet d'adaptation initie puis abandonne par Martin Scorsese. Je lui souhaite bon courage, car la barre est haute. Tres haute.

A bit long, but utterly engrossing.  The police procedure piece, in particular, reminded me of "M."  Loved how everyone was coping with the heat.  The drug alley scene was haunting.  Loved the soot and noise of the ghetto.  The closing scene blew me away.  If you love cinema, put the effort into plugging through this one.

Shoes.  Kidnapping.  Noir.  Kurosawa.  High and Low is an absolutely stunning crime film, executed perfectly.  Fantastic, powerful, and gripping- why this film isn't ranked up with Seven Samurai and Rashomon is beyond me.

Kurosawa and Mifune team up for a modern masterpiece about kidnapping and still-feudal relationships in post-WWII Japan.  Huge chunks of this were "borrowed" for the Mel Gibson/Ron Howard flick 'Ransom.'

Kurosawa was long, and accurately, considered the most Westernized of Japanese directors.  Seldom is it more evident than here, in [i]Tengoku to jigoku[/i] (literally translates to "Heaven and Hell"), which is actually genuinely based on an American mystery novel.  I must admit that I've never read an Ed McBain novel, though I may have to start here.  This movie is based on the novel [i]King's Ransom[/i], though I have no idea, obviously, how closely.  Of course, Kurosawa has transferred the whole thing to Japan, as I'm not sure he ever set anything anywhere else.  He even works in that most Japanese of landmarks, Mount Fuji.  He works in the bullet train.  This is a very Japanese version of a very American story, and I think perhaps only Kurosawa was capable of doing that sort of thing.

Kingo Gondo (Toshirô Mifune, of course) is an executive at the National Shoe Company.  The other executives want to take over the company and make poor-quality shoes which will sell more and sell quickly, because they will wear out.  Gondo wants to make good shoes, which will not sell as often but will be worth the price.  He has slowly been buying up stock so that he will have enough to take over the company and run things his way.  However, he receives a phone call saying that his son, Jun (Toshio Egi), has been kidnapped.  However, it is not Jun.  Jun traded clothes with Shinichi Aoki (Masahiko Shamazu), the son of the chauffeur (Yutaka Sada), and the wrong boy has been taken.  Gondo must decide whether to pay the ransom as Aoki begs or to keep up with his plans of taking over the company, which has tied up all of his money.

What I find interesting about the story is how beloved Gondo is by the actual workers of the factory.  The other executives?  Not so fond.  In fact, the workers suggest to the detectives that the executives might be behind the kidnapping.  They themselves wish to help find the missing boy, and public support, once the story is out, is all behind Gondo, and the rest of the executives are shamed.  Women, in fact, are said to be boycotting National Shoes.  This does not stop the machinations, of course, but Gondo is seen as almost saintly in his treatment of workers, consumers, and company.  The detectives, who are just doing their jobs, seem to like him as well, and Aoki assumes almost without considering the issue that Gondo will pay his son's ransom.

I also like that Kurosawa chooses to show us Gondo's hesitance.  (It also delights me that the author of the original book is credited, in the Japanese, as "Edo Makubein.")  Gondo genuinely wants to help Aoki, of whom he is clearly fond.  Certainly Jun and Shinichi are shown to be real friends.  However, Gondo has everything tied up in this deal.  The stock is going to cost him 150 million yen.  He has leveraged [i]everything[/i].  To pay the ransom will take the 50 million yen that is to be his down payment.  Not only will the deal fall through, he will be wiped out.  In fact, Aoki will lose his job--but Aoki cares far less about his job than he does his son, obviously.  Gondo's choice will change things for an enormous number of people, and Kurosawa makes us feel that choice.

This is not Kurosawa's best work.  I'm still holding out judgement as to what will be, as there are several important ones we haven't gotten to yet and won't for some time.  (We're only on "H," after all, and two of the most famous ones start with "R"!)  However, as with some other directors, even his substandard works are better than the best works of several other directors, and not just your Uwe Bolls and your Michael Bays.  And that right there?  That's the only time you'll see me compare Akira Kurosawa with Uwe Boll and Michael Bay.

Could Akira Kurosawa make a bad film? The answer is no. In High And Low (Heaven And Hell in its original Japanese) Toshiro Mifune plays an executive who mortgages everything that he owns to take control of the shoe company he's worked for since he was 16. But just as he thought everything was going according to plan, something unexpected happens...
Brilliant crime film from the legendary Kurosawa -- deeply recommended!

Truly the Emperor of Cinema, Kurosawa has panache of creating some of the most memorable characters in film and attracting a plethora of Japan's most respected talents. Our empathy reaches out to Gondo as he struggles in his impossible situation, while our hearts bleed  for his chauffeur's anguish for the safe return of his son. Meanwhile, edge of your seat suspense, tension and drama is heighted by what is NOT being said between characters. Kurosawa's choice of changing the POV from Gondo to Det. Tokura and finally to the kidnapper himself, is bold, risky and masterfully pulled off. This gives us glimpses into each lead's mindset with the two most important being Gondo in his desire to cement a secure future for his family, and the envy driving Ginjirô Takeuchi to his crime. Both Gondo and Takeuchi represent the same demographic, and Kurosawa uses these characters to represent the point that we are all the subjects of our environments, and given the right (or wrong) circumstances, we are all capable of unthinkable deeds. This point reaches its dramatic apex in the final scene as Gondo sits across from Takeuchi; with each cut, Kurosawa brings the prior's reflection ever closer to the latter's until, finally, both faces overlap. ...Chillingly brilliant.
kurosawa puts his distinctive stamp on the police drama. it's no hyperbole to say that the final scene is one of the greatest scenes ever filmed. the film as a whole is criminally underrated.
Extremely well-acted and directed.  A bit lengthy, but the story keeps you interested.

Amazing, really hooked me despite the length. The first hour is a little slow, but the detective story and social comments at the end easily made that up. Great acting (comedic and dramatic) and a very well-written story to work with. I can't stop watching the train scene.

ok..not much to say about the film from a master.. everything is  expectedly well-executed :extremely fluid in camera movement, highly-composed within-frame mise-en-scene/ blocking....  i thought i was watching another hitchcock lol.. maybe it's due to the detective story plot.. the last scene makes me think of the last scene in psycho...
High and Low is a comment on social class, wrapped in a superb human drama, wrapped in a taut and suspenseful crimel thriller.

Easily now one of my favorite films. From start to finish "High and Low" has you hooked, begenning with a somewhat unrelated sequences to the rest of the film. (main plot wize, but it does have a purpose) Fantastic acting by Mifune and the 'wrong doer' Visually compelling and thematicaly potent. I did not expect liking this so much.

More than just an examination of class, this film explores how both classes (high and low) afford opportunities for self-sacrifice and reconciliation (heaven) or hatred and degradation (hell). Dantesque.
A surprisingly engrossing film that was way ahead of it's time- and is all the more pertinent today. Try counting how many times you see something that a thousand other filmmakers have mimicked.

A masterful piece of cinema that kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire duration. Mifune, Tastuya Nakadai and the actor who played the kidnapper are all fantastic, the cinematography is also something to admire as well. Kurosawa's complete use of the frame- no space is wasted, the framing is extremely precise and the shot compositions are done from all the right angles. The pacing and the action which sums up to the editing is incredibly well done. A fantastic film, it's required viewing for any film buff.

Incredibly layered and complex work from Akira Kurosawa, and one of his rare instances of a contemporary movie. The visuals are stunning, crammed with elaborate details, and though the plot is adapted from a straightforward American potboiler, Kurosawa transfers it to Japanese society and creates many memorable sequences of devotion and class differences. Especially great is the bullet train sequence: the spatial details and rhythms are incredible. One of his very best works.

What a wonderful film this is!  "High and Low" is a film showcasing post-World War II Japanese society.  Commenting on the upper, middle, and lower class of the Americanized country, the film's real brilliance lies in, of course, the cinematography.  Kurosawa was a trained painter and he easily translates his wonderful sense of style to film by using widescreen.  Rarely do I see films where the entire frame is being used in such a grand, yet personal way.  

Everything in this film works really well except when the cops decide to go on a manhunt so they can sentence capital punishment to the "kidnapper."  The film enters "Hell" and becomes surreal and horrific as we are shown zombie-like heroin addicts and a perpetrator who hides behind mirrored sunglasses.  While this sequence has some of the best photography of the entire film, I don't think it really captures that "lower" part of society that well.  Nevertheless, it still works for the most part in context with the rest of the film and doesn't detract fully from the overall experience.

"High and Low" has wonderful messages throughout and all of the characters are complex and interesting.  When the "bad guy" screams at the end of the film we can't help but wonder if the "protagonist" doesn't feel the same way.  This is a beautiful film and I highly recommend it.

Ok, I seem to be watching aton of Kurosawa flicks right now. This one threw me off a bit as it was a contemporary film for 63' and I'm not a fan of the decor thena nd the first third seemed like a stage play turned into a film and then Kurosawa switched gears and it really opneed up and became a who-dun-it kind of film. Very well done!

The social part of Kurosawa's work, slayer of hypocrisy and injustice. The intensity goes a little bit down along the movie but that's only because of the power of the beginning. One on the best movie ever about dilemma.

Superb crime/detective drama, with elaborate characterization of main roles. From the technical aspect, I have not seen better use of widescreen resolution, every shot was amazing. Also, scenery was very well used, particularly in the apartment. My favorite scene is definitely in drug street, where junkies look like zombies, in horror-like atmosphere, I really wish Kurosawa did some horrors or sth like that.

Master filmmaker Akira Kurosawa's kidnapping drama is an absolute classic of its genre and a hallmark of Japanese cinema, even though it is based on an 87th Precinct novel by Ed McBain. Equal parts moral drama, police procedural, and psychological thriller with strong performances - particularly from the always fascinating Toshiro Mifune - and memorable visuals. It does have it's slow, talky moments, but overall this is a smart and masterfully crafted masterpiece.

Akira Kurosawa is associated with Samurai films a little too much, with the action extravaganza "Seven Samurai", the Macbeth-Kabuki Theatre fusion called "Throne Of Blood" and his Man-With-No-Name influencing duo of "Yojimbo" and "Sanjuro", it's not hard to see why this generalisation exists (Can't forget about "Kagemusha" and "Ran" made at the twilight of his career). But with his films, there was also a real compassion and sentiment which sometimes boiled over (see "Ikiru", a non-Samurai film), but when it didn't boil over, the results were particularly amazing. 

After his "Yojimbo/Sanjuro" double bill, Akira Kurosawa took on an Ed McBain novel, and made a fantastic crime thriller and one of the best police procedurals you'll ever see (It's a personal favourite of the Coen Brothers): "High And Low" (The literal meaning is "Heaven And Hell", but let's not get too picky).

It starts off (and stays for practically the entire first third of the film) in a large house overlooking the Downtown area of Tokyo. The owner of the house is Kingo Gondo (In another wonderful charismatic-yet-restrained performance by Toshiro Mifune). Kingo has worked his way up through his shoe company (a big deal in social circles in Japan) to the point where he can move enough money around to become the leading shareholder (the other shareholders want him out of the company because he doesn't want to make poor quality shoes for high sales). But before his deal to takeover the company can go through, he gets a phonecall saying that his son has been kidnapped, and to pay the ransom would leave him financially ruined. But there's a twist: The kidnappers took his chauffeur's son instead, but the ransom remains the same. Will Kingo ruin himself financially to save the life of a child who isn't his?

The second half of the film involves the Police's attempts to find out who the kidnapper was. It's a nice shift from the claustrophobic living room of the first third, into the real world where the Police use all their manpower to figure out every single detail. The procedure is done in a meticulous style that is often missing from crime thrillers made today, as the Police Chief narrow down their targets until they believe they've found their man. But a simple kidnapping charge isn't enough, they want him to hang.

Kurosawa's camera manages to capture the spotless veneer of the businessman's appartment, and can contrast it with the dirty stench that permeates throughout the Downtown area of Tokyo, as the areas of "Heaven & Hell" are clearly delineated geographically. The performances are wonderful from everyone, particularly Toshiro Mifune and Tatsuya Nakadai as the Police Inspector. It's a fantastic crime drama that lets the plot unravel at its own pace, the Police slowly piecing together the criminal's every step before zeroing in on their man. The ending shows the chasm between Heaven & Hell, and Kurosawa informs that the only way to reach Heaven is to do things the honourable way.

[font=Georgia][color=black]([i]'High and Low' [/i] Kurosawa, Akira; 1962)[/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]This was a Kurosawa film that really didn't sound all that compelling to me. It starts out as a gripping abduction film with a unique moral twist-- the opening scene of the National Shoes executives reminded me of [i]Ran[/i] -- before warping into an exhaustively detailed procedural that would certainly impress[i] Zodiac[/i] helmer David Fincher. The end result is a sprawling crime drama, easily one of Kurosawa's masterpieces.[/color][/font]
 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]He has a defnite feel and natural observation for his characters, and it's no different here. The sheer complexity of the film, either in its first of second half, is enough to warrant keeping notes -- it's a brilliant script as always.[/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[img]http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Film/Pix/pictures/2008/10/29/kobal_highandlow460.jpg[/img]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]Another thing I really noticed here -- perhaps its the 2.35 aspect ratio on the Criterion disc I watched -- is that Kurosawa really manages his widescreen angles beautifully. He can get almost every character in the same shot, utilizing the foreground as well as the background advantageously. It allows less cutting, longer takes, higher drama and another thing I really enjoyed -- very little close-ups. [/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]I keep hearing people knock Toshiro Mifune on these journals, but the guy continues to impress me endlessly. He had the best performance in [i]Seven Samurai[/i], and although his screen time here is very minimal outside of the first hour, he makes it count.[/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][i]High and Low[/i] was certainly a delightful surprise, as I had little interest in seeing it. The switch from abduction film to procedural got me on the edge of my seat and it's fun to think about the different and multiple meaning of the film's title. Do check it out if you haven't seen it.[/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]([i]'Ikiru' [/i] Kurosawa, Akira; 1952)[/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]I literally just finished watching [i]Ikiru,[/i] and it's definitely Kurosawa's most seemingly personal and strange film that I've seen from him so far. Essentially about the quest for fulfillment of one man, Watanabe (the always great Takashi Shimura), before his inevitable death of stomach cancer, it's the kind of film that feels like as mysterious and masterful as Orson Welles' [i]Citizen Kane[/i], while coming up just short.[/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]I liked the majority of the first 90 minutes or so -- which can be easily seperated from the final 60 -- but a few things didn't completely work. First off, Watanabe's dialogue feels overwritten. I get that he's supposed to be a stumbling, inconcise kind of guy, but why does he have to say, "in other words" every time he feels like he needs to clarify himself? Unless this is a mistake by the Criterion english subtitles, it's doesn't feel natural.[/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]Secondly, Watanabe's quest for a purpose in last remaining 6 months has its hits (his relationship with a young female ex-co worker) and misses (a night on the town with a friend who feels pity for the sickly city official). Obviously, the entire sequence is well-shot, as is the entirety of the film, but it struck me as an unnecessarily lenghty detour.[/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[img]http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Film/Pix/pictures/2008/07/04/Ikiru_460.jpg[/img]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]However, the final 50 minutes or so of [i]Ikiru[/i] is easily the best stretch of film-making I've seen from Kurosawa -- I'm talking brilliant. Every frame is full of redemption and hope as Watanabe's co-workers sit around his wake, piecing his life together that was a mystery even to his only son. Some of the attendees are touched, some unmoved, some so drunk that they act influenced by his final moments, but have clearly proven these remarks to be hollow when back at work in the very next scene.[/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]In the end, the result is, even with a few flaws, one of Kurosawa's more deeply-felt masterpieces. With [i]Seven Samurai, High and Low [/i]and[i] Ikiru[/i], he has as extensive and diverse a body of work with just those three films than most directors could ever even hope for -- I can't wait to watch some more.[/color][/font]
[font=Georgia][color=#000000][/color][/font] 
[font=Georgia][color=#000000]By the way, for those of you who fancy yourselves Kurosawa experts (ryanator), do you remember that final scene with the park and the bridge? Didn't that look like the exact same bridge with the polluted river running under it that was featured so prominently in [i]Drunken Angel[/i]? I could be imagining it, but it seemed like the exact same location to me.[/color][/font]
Amazing. More and more, I'm convinced there has never been a better director than Kurosawa.

This film noir from legendary director Akira Kurosawa is suspense and drama at their absolute best.  Beautifully shot, delicately directed, and magnificently performed, HIGH AND LOW tells the story of a man's moral dilemma when confronted with a kidnapper's ruthless plot.  The man at first believes that his son has been kidnapped, and he agrees to pay the ransom.  However, he then learns that his son is all right; the kidnapper got the wrong boy.  What does he do?  The second half of the film centers on the kidnapper and the quest to get him.  A fantastic motion picture.

A good suspense film from Kurosawa. Kingo Gondo (Toshiro Mifune) is faced with a dilemma when money he has allocated to take over his company becomes the money he must use to save his kidnapped son. Things become further complicated when Gondo learns that it is his chauffeur's son that has been kidnapped. Will the greedy executive pay the money or go on with his plan? Great performances by Mifune and fellow acting star Tatsuya Nakadai as the investigator on the kidnapper's tail. Overlooked film from the old master.

I don't know, maybe I am the only cinephile who doesn't love Kurosawa, but I just don't get it. Tatsuya Nakadai, my favourite actor is completely wasted in this film. Everything is incredibly stagey and stuffy, as one would expect from Kurosawa. I do enjoy the police procedural parts, but I never find myself terribly interested in any of the characters.

One of Kurosawa's best. In a perfect world, his social justice films would overshadow the samurai films. Mifune dominates the front half of this kidnapping caper, and the back half is a great police procedural. Gorgeously shot and well-paced.
A really good Kurosawa flick (one of  the seemingly few that didn't involve feudal Japan) that serves well both as a suspense thriller and a police procedural.

Very interesting film. Kurosawa seems to have no problem swapping into a contemporary setting. This film reminds me a lot of Ransom (or should I say Ransom reminds me a lot of this) in that same feeling of high society versus low. Usually it seems that the wealthy are depicted as corrupt and the impoverished as the victim or underdog, and its interesting to see the reverse side.  I think Ransom is better in its pacing and handling of the suspense, in High and Low the transition from the executives conversation to the ransom call seemed a bit strange to me. 

The primary difference I think between the two films is that Ransom uses the plot to tell the story in an exciting and suspensful way; Kurosawa seems to use it more as a social commentary on Reconstructed Japan. But what is Kurosawa trying to say with this film? That the rich can be moral too? That sacrifice does not go unrepaid? Is he simply showing the stark contrast of living between the two sects of society? I'm not entirely sure, but its still a pretty cool ransom flick.
What's that you say?  Toshiro Mifune is brilliant even as a non-samurai character?  Yes, it's true.  Mifune and Kurosawa both deliver with this film.

First I will talk about the pile.  [i]Vantage Point[/i] was a movie that I'm pretty sure they tried to make as ridiculous and boring as possible.  Hey guys, let's show the same event over and over.  I don't mind minor repetitions in films, but there is no need to repeat stuff in slight variation *cough, [i]Run Lola Run[/i], cough*, but let's be honest that was just the gimmick to get people to see it.  Oh, and a twist, Matthew Fox's character is a terrorist, yet he is assigned to guard the President of the United States.  Man, that would make his job easy[img]http://images.rottentomatoes.com/images/user/smilies/rolleyes.gif[/img].  Also, Secret Service would never discharge their weapons in a crowd of people like they did unless there was immediate danger.  But let's be fair, I'm not an expert on how the Secret Service works, I'm just not retarded.  Also, it's a Hollywood film where nearly all of the stars of the film are good guys, how do you think it ends?

[center][img]http://whatilove.files.wordpress.com/2008/07/vantagepoint.jpg[/img]

[i]High and Low[/i] was riveting at its best, but at its worst, it is boring.  With a great start, a 15-20 minute lull, and a super ending, it was hardly a chore, yet at the same time, I think some scenes could have easily been cut down to make this 120 minutes instead of 140 minutes.  I'm sorry, but the only reason a film should be over 2 hours is if the movie has more to say and can go the whole runtime without dragging.  I actually watched this over two sittings because during the lull, I had to take a break for a while.  Looking back, if I had known the film was going to finish as strong as it did, I would have finished it in one sitting.
